title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" under the Small Business Act. It also establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education in the Administration develops innovative information and resources for prospective entrepreneurs and small businesses. The Director manages online courses, publications, and youth entrepreneurship programs. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education in the Administration oversees youth entrepreneurship programs, coordinates with private sector partners on financial literacy, and provides assistance to individuals interested in small business concerns. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education oversees youth entrepreneurship programs and provides assistance to individuals interested in small business concerns. The National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program aims to establish a program for grants to nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance to schools for promoting entrepreneurship. Nonprofit organizations, including small business development centers, SCORE chapters, women's business centers, and other resource partners, provide technical assistance to schools for entrepreneurship programs. Organizations applying for grants must describe project goals, list partners, and submit necessary information. A report must be submitted to the Associate Administrator within one year of receiving the grant. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must submit a report within a year detailing individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information. Authorization of appropriations is set at $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2013-2015. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education is required to submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report should describe exemplary programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as summarize entrepreneurial education and training programs conducted by the Federal Government. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education identifies exemplary national, regional, state, and local programs, and summarizes entrepreneurial education initiatives by the Federal Government, state and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. SEC. 4. MASTER OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION SCHOLARSHIP PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of recipients must be students from institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The scholarship recipients must be students at institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The activities support various small business and entrepreneurial projects. Each student has a mentor to help relate their academic study to the assistance provided. Data collection is required for both scholarship recipients and small business/entrepreneurs receiving assistance. The student receiving a scholarship must provide information on the use of assistance and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan. The scholarship recipient must provide post-graduation information for 3 years. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan with repayment terms specified by the Administrator. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2013-2015. No scholarships can be awarded after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address regional challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify public-private issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, inventors, and entrepreneurs, and promote outreach to various organizations for research and business plans. The Administrator will organize a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans addressing regional challenges. The Administrator will organize a national conference where 11 employees will select the best research and business plans from each region to address identified issues. The Administrator will designate panel members from the principal and regional offices. A $50,000 grant will be awarded to selected plans, with recipients required to submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for Administrator appropriations. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation.
